page.title: Wowza Support Ticket 답변 : 형식적인.
page.content: Your Deployment Questions, Answered       While most deployments need one server, some need dozens. Here are the answers to some common questions about building your infrastructure.                             Q: How many incoming streams can a single server handle?                      A: The number of incoming streams a single server instance can support greatly depends on workflow requirements and server hardware. Here are two common examples:                 HD Broadcaster Workflow: Send a 4 Mbps bitrate stream to Wowza Streaming Engine to transcode for ABR streaming. While done in real time, transcoding is a compute-intensive process; workflows using the Wowza Transcoder will often be limited by the computational capacity of their server. We recommend transcoding workflows use compute optimized servers, and transcode two to six streams per server. See our transcoder benchmarks for more details.         UGC Server Provider: Capture video from a mobile or desktop application and send a 1 Mbps stream to Wowza Streaming Engine to package and route for delivery. Broadcasters of SD content often choose passthrough workflows for their economics. In this use case, a single server can ingest and package hundreds of streams; servers will be limited on bandwidth.                                      Q: How many outgoing streams can a single server handle?                       A: The number of concurrent outgoing streams for a single server will depend on your stream bitrate and the available network. A general rule of thumb when calculating server capacity is to keep your total bandwidth at less than 80% of total capacity.        stream bitrate * peak concurrent viewers < 80% of total available bandwidth                                         Q: How do I scale my delivery?                       A: Many deployments can use a single instance of Wowza Streaming Engine to provide both origin packaging services and stream delivery. However, if you need to scale, Wowza offers a few options:                 Use Wowza CDN to quickly scale your streaming affordably.         Use Wowza load balancing and scaling tools to build your own edge.          Push to third parties, using stream targets.         Create HTTP Pull Workflows to deliver your content.                                           Still have questions? Check out our deployment example guide.                              From(웹페이지로 보기) <http://wowza-1.hs-sites.com/your-deployment-questions-answered?ecid=ACsprvtUXa2wkucRFBZytEilUtuuXwjBl0I0y7L6IujD5pcsvtSg98JSeTCbk-cfY5Y0hxAUHRY-&utm_campaign=trial-drip&utm_source=hs_automation&utm_medium=email&utm_content=49566890&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9t9jKm1oCDpZZaSZ0f97puhMkvzN37u2MqdGnE8FwVAXpmwQvbrUCVifJvTJI8CHpxUJx2_M2S61hr5xvUq0vID7qjDA&_hsmi=49566890>
page.html:
Your Deployment Questions, Answered 

While most deployments need one server, some need dozens. Here are the answers to some common questions about building your infrastructure.

  

Q: How many incoming streams can a single server handle?

A: The number of incoming streams a single server instance can support greatly depends on workflow requirements and server hardware. Here are two common examples:

  • HD Broadcaster Workflow: Send a 4 Mbps bitrate stream to Wowza Streaming Engine to transcode for ABR streaming. While done in real time, transcoding is a compute-intensive process; workflows using the Wowza Transcoder will often be limited by the computational capacity of their server. We recommend transcoding workflows use compute optimized servers, and transcode two to six streams per server. See our transcoder benchmarks for more details.
  • UGC Server Provider: Capture video from a mobile or desktop application and send a 1 Mbps stream to Wowza Streaming Engine to package and route for delivery. Broadcasters of SD content often choose passthrough workflows for their economics. In this use case, a single server can ingest and package hundreds of streams; servers will be limited on bandwidth.
Q: How many outgoing streams can a single server handle? 

A: The number of concurrent outgoing streams for a single server will depend on your stream bitrate and the available network. A general rule of thumb when calculating server capacity is to keep your total bandwidth at less than 80% of total capacity.

stream bitrate * peak concurrent viewers < 80% of total available bandwidth  

 
Q: How do I scale my delivery? 

A: Many deployments can use a single instance of Wowza Streaming Engine to provide both origin packaging services and stream delivery. However, if you need to scale, Wowza offers a few options:

  • Use Wowza CDN to quickly scale your streaming affordably.
  • Use Wowza load balancing and scaling tools to build your own edge. 
  • Push to third parties, using stream targets.
  • Create HTTP Pull Workflows to deliver your content.

 

 Still have questions? Check out our deployment example guide.
